<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 186, 171, 201]]<|/det|>
# PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 206, 366, 222]]<|/det|>
Paper 2 Multiple Choice (Extended)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[782, 185, 907, 243]]<|/det|>
0625/22 May/June 2017 45 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 248, 588, 291]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: Multiple Choice Answer Sheet Soft clean eraser Soft pencil (type B or HB recommended)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 312, 388, 329]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 343, 237, 358]]<|/det|>
Write in soft pencil.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 358, 504, 373]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 373, 892, 402]]<|/det|>
Write your name, Centre number and candidate number on the Answer Sheet in the spaces provided unless this has been done for you.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 400, 383, 416]]<|/det|>
DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 430, 892, 460]]<|/det|>
There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions. For each question there are four possible answers A, B, C and D.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 459, 890, 475]]<|/det|>
Choose the one you consider correct and record your choice in soft pencil on the separate Answer Sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 488, 556, 505]]<|/det|>
Read the instructions on the Answer Sheet very carefully.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 518, 764, 534]]<|/det|>
Each correct answer will score one mark. A mark will not be deducted for a wrong answer.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 534, 467, 549]]<|/det|>
Any rough working should be done in this booklet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 549, 359, 564]]<|/det|>
Electronic calculators may be used.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 564, 630, 580]]<|/det|>
Take the weight of \(1.0\mathrm{kg}\) to be \(10\mathrm{N}\) (acceleration of free fall \(= 10\mathrm{m / s}^2\) ).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 96, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 71, 798, 91]]<|/det|>
What is the most accurate and precise method to measure the thickness of a coin?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 100, 133, 118]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 100, 415, 119]]<|/det|>
Use a micrometer screw gauge.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 125, 133, 144]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 125, 556, 144]]<|/det|>
Use a ruler and look at the scale perpendicularly.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 152, 133, 170]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 152, 346, 170]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 178, 133, 196]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 178, 690, 196]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 284, 425, 302]]<|/det|>

<label>14</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 390, 836, 408]]<|/det|>
Brownian motion is observed when using a microscope to look at smoke particles in air.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 420, 561, 437]]<|/det|>
What causes the smoke particles to move at random?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 448, 134, 467]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 448, 490, 467]]<|/det|>
Smoke particles are hit by air molecules.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 475, 131, 494]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 475, 650, 494]]<|/det|>
Smoke particles are moved by convection currents in the air.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 502, 131, 520]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 502, 700, 520]]<|/det|>

<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 528, 527, 546]]<|/det|>

<label>15</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 572, 920, 605]]<|/det|>
A student blows air through a liquid using a straw. This causes the liquid to evaporate quickly and therefore to cool.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 616, 594, 634]]<|/det|>
Which statement explains why the remaining liquid cools?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 644, 133, 663]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 644, 665, 663]]<|/det|>
Slower-moving molecules are carried away by the air bubbles.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 670, 133, 689]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 670, 541, 689]]<|/det|>
The air molecules conduct heat from the liquid.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 696, 133, 715]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 696, 546, 715]]<|/det|>
The air sets up convection currents in the liquid.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 723, 133, 740]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 723, 556, 740]]<|/det|>

<label>16</label>

<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 796, 818, 814]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 822, 133, 841]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 822, 833, 840]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 850, 133, 867]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 850, 772, 867]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 875, 133, 893]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 875, 787, 892]]<|/det|>
the energy needed to produce unit temperature increase of unit volume of ice

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 131, 492, 149]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[161, 156, 834, 425]]<|/det|>

<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 466, 589, 485]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 494, 133, 511]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 494, 551, 511]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 520, 133, 539]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 520, 514, 539]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 546, 771, 565]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 106, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 893, 89]]<|/det|> A copper bar and a wooden bar are joined. A piece of paper is wrapped tightly around the join. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 102, 920, 135]]<|/det|> The bar is heated strongly at the centre for a short time, and the paper goes brown on one side only. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[371, 144, 621, 265]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 278, 734, 295]]<|/det|> Which side goes brown, and what does this show about wood and copper? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 307, 611, 437]]<|/det|>
brown sidewoodcopper
Acopperconductorinsulator
Bcopperinsulatorconductor
Cwoodconductorinsulator
Dwoodinsulatorconductor

<label>19</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 71, 549, 89]]<|/det|>
Different waves hit barriers with different sized gaps.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 101, 306, 119]]<|/det|>
The waves will diffract.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 131, 556, 149]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 106, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|> Light travels in a vacuum and then enters a glass block. The speed of the light in the glass block is \(2.0 \times 10^{8} \text{m/s}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 117, 546, 135]]<|/det|> Which statement about the speed of light is correct? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 145, 133, 163]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 144, 636, 163]]<|/det|> The speed in a vacuum is 1.5 times the speed in the glass. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 172, 133, 190]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 171, 662, 190]]<|/det|> The speed in the glass is the same as the speed in a vacuum. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 198, 133, 216]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 198, 636, 216]]<|/det|> The speed in the glass is 1.5 times the speed in a vacuum. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 225, 133, 243]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 225, 685, 243]]<|/det|> The speed in the glass is \(1.0 \times 10^{8}\) times the speed in a vacuum. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 270, 106, 288]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 270, 922, 303]]<|/det|> A fire alarm is not loud enough and the pitch is too low. An engineer adjusts the alarm so that it produces a louder note of a higher pitch. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 312, 777, 330]]<|/det|> What effect does this have on the amplitude and on the frequency of the sound? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 342, 430, 470]]<|/det|>
amplitudefrequency

Dsmallersmaller

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 107, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>25</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 850, 89]]<|/det|>
A magnet near a coil of wire is attracted to the coil only when there is a current in the coil.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 102, 524, 120]]<|/det|>
Which statement explains this force of attraction?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 131, 133, 148]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 131, 526, 148]]<|/det|>
The coil of wire has its own gravitational field.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 157, 133, 175]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 157, 470, 175]]<|/det|>
The coil of wire is made from soft iron.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 184, 133, 202]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 183, 599, 201]]<|/det|>
The current in the coil of wire creates a magnetic field.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 210, 133, 227]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 208, 668, 225]]<|/det|>
The current in the coil of wire induces a charge on the magnet.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 500, 804, 518]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 71, 106, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 435, 88]]<|/det|> Which particle has a negative charge? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 100, 139, 117]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 100, 292, 117]]<|/det|> an alpha particle <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 125, 136, 144]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 125, 248, 144]]<|/det|> an electron <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 152, 136, 170]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 152, 235, 170]]<|/det|> a neutron <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 178, 136, 196]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 178, 225, 196]]<|/det|> a proton <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 222, 106, 241]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 222, 500, 241]]<|/det|> A type of nuclear reaction takes place in stars. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 253, 468, 271]]<|/det|> Which row describes this type of reaction? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 280, 756, 411]]<|/det|>
nuclear reactionnuclei formedenergy transfer
Afissionlarger than original nucleireleased
Bfissionsmaller than original nucleiabsorbed
Cfusionlarger than original nucleireleased
Dfusionsmaller than original nucleiabsorbed
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 438, 106, 457]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 438, 480, 457]]<|/det|> A sample of radioactive isotope is decaying. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 469, 465, 487]]<|/det|> The nuclei of which atoms will decay first? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 497, 133, 515]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 497, 662, 515]]<|/det|> It is impossible to know because radioactive decay is random. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 523, 133, 542]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 523, 677, 542]]<|/det|> It is impossible to know unless the age of the material is known. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 551, 133, 568]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 549, 873, 567]]<|/det|> The atoms near the centre will decay first because they are surrounded by more atoms. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 575, 133, 593]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 575, 890, 593]]<|/det|> The atoms near the surface will decay first because the radiation can escape more easily. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 619, 106, 638]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 619, 744, 638]]<|/det|> A sample of a radioactive isotope emits particles at a rate of 240 per minute. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 650, 672, 668]]<|/det|> After 48 hours the rate of emission has decreased to 15 per minute. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 680, 507, 698]]<|/det|> What is the half-life of the radioactive material? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 707, 133, 726]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 707, 233, 726]]<|/det|> 4.0 hours <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 707, 303, 726]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[316, 707, 400, 726]]<|/det|> 8.0 hours <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 707, 470, 726]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[480, 707, 562, 726]]<|/det|> 12 hours <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[615, 707, 636, 726]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[650, 707, 730, 726]]<|/det|> 16 hours

This is produced for each series of examinations and is freely available to download at www.cie.org.uk after the live examination series.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 916, 920, 939]]<|/det|>
Cambridge International Examinations is part of the Cambridge Assessment Group. Cambridge Assessment is the brand name of University of Cambridge Local Examinations Syndicate (UCLES), which is itself a department of the University of Cambridge.
